revision.comment: Robot - Moving category People from San Antonio, Texas to [[:Category:People from San Antonio]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2016 September 6]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name=Robert Wesley Colglazier, Jr. |birth_date={{birth date|1904|10|18}} |death_date={{death date and age|1993|1|23|1904|10|18}} |image= Robert Wesley Colglazier.jpg |caption= Colglazier as a Lieutenant General in 1960. |nickname= |birth_place=[[St. Louis, Missouri]] |death_place=[[San Antonio, Texas]] |placeofburial=[[Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery]] |placeofburial_label= Place of burial |allegiance= [[United States|United States of America]] |branch= [[United States Army]] |serviceyears=1925-1966 |rank= [[File:US-O9 insignia.svg|35px]] [[Lieutenant General (United States)|Lieutenant General]] |unit= |commands=[[United States Army Europe|U.S. Army Europe]] Communications Zone
[[Fourth United States Army]] |battles=[[World War II]]
[[Korean War]]
[[Vietnam War]] |awards=[[Distinguished Service Medal (U.S. Army)|Distinguished Service Medal]]
[[Legion of Merit]]
[[Bronze Star Medal]]
[[Army Commendation Medal]]
[[Order of the British Empire]]
French [[Legion of Honor]]
French [[Croix de guerre#French Croix de guerre|Croix de Guerre]] |relations= |laterwork=President, Colglazier Construction Company,
Councilman-At-Large, Texas A&M University Association of Former Students }} '''Robert Wesley Colglazier, Jr.''' (October 18, 1904â€“January 23, 1993) was a [[United States Army]] [[Lieutenant General (United States)|Lieutenant General]]. He was prominent as the highest-ranking member of the [[United States Army Reserve|Army Reserve]] on duty with the [[Regular Army]] in the 1960s, and as commander of the [[Fourth United States Army]]. In the 1950s and 1960s Colglazier was recognized as one of the military's foremost experts on logistics management.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5QUrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GJgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6152,7280432&dq=colglazier+army&hl=en Newspaper article, Leaves Army], Reading Eagle, January 15, 1966 ==Early life== Colglazier graduated from [[Texas A&M University]] in 1925 with a degree in civil engineering, and began employment with his family's construction company, [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio's]] Colglazier Construction Company.[https://books.google.com/books?id=5KPZPwcF7ygC&q=colglazier+texas+a%26m+1925&dq=colglazier+texas+a%26m+1925&hl=en&ei=wKjhTc2FHKaN0AG_97CxBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAw Army Reserve Magazine], published by US Army Reserve, Volume 12, 1966[https://books.google.com/books?id=dqCWy9A-KFIC&pg=PA315&dq=colglazier+army&hl=en&ei=DsfhTbXoIMnu0gGXhe2HBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAzge#v=onepage&q=colglazier%20army&f=false Keepers of the spirit: the Corps of Cadets at Texas A&M University, 1876-2001], by John A. Adams, 2001, page 315 During the [[Great Depression]] Colglazier worked as director of the operations division for the [[Works Progress Administration]] in [[Texas]].[https://books.google.com/books?ei=c6XhTdW_C8Tq0gGex9WdBw&ct=result&id=sShQAAAAYAAJ&dq=robert+colglazier+works+progress+administration&q=colglazier#search_anchor Engineering News-Record], published by McGraw-Hill, Volume 126, Part 2, 1941, page 114 ==Start of military career== Colglazier received a commission as a [[Second Lieutenant#United States|Second Lieutenant]] upon graduating from college, and began a career in the Army Reserve.[https://books.google.com/books?ei=u7ThTfabF6nw0gGC0ZijBw&ct=result&id=zoAXAQAAMAAJ&dq=robert+colglazier+engineer&q=colglazier#search_anchor Army and Navy Journal], 1936, Volume 74, Issues 1-26, page 39[https://books.google.com/books?ei=O7HhTeWUM8bf0QHx2On3Bw&ct=result&id=iPseAAAAMAAJ&dq=robert+colglazier+army+reserve+1925&q=colglazier#search_anchor The Military Engineer], published by the Society of American Military Engineers, 1948, Volume 40, page 137 ==World War II== In 1941 Colglazier was called to active duty for [[World War II]]. After returning to active duty as a [[Captain (United States)|Captain]], he played a key role in the planning and organization for construction of [[the Pentagon]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=Dr0UIZJw58YC&pg=PA38&dq=robert+colglazier+pentagon&hl=en&ei=oaLhTcWaBuXV0QGU4ozFBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=robert%20colglazier%20pentagon&f=false The Pentagon: a History; the Untold Story of the Wartime Race to Build the Pentagon -- And to Restore it 60 Years Later], by Steve Vogel, 2008, page 38[https://books.google.com/books?id=x1QYAQAAIAAJ&q=robert+colglazier+pentagon&dq=robert+colglazier+pentagon&hl=en&ei=PqThTYHuKsb20gGN8tmcBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFIQ6AEwCQ Robert W. Colglazier entry], Guide to the Oral History Collection, Texas A&M University, published by the University, 1988, page 25 He attained the rank of [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] while carrying out engineer staff officer assignments in [[Northern Ireland]], [[England]], [[North African Campaign|North Africa]] [[Italy]] and [[France]]. From 1942 to 1943 Colglazier was an engineer plans officer for the [[Mediterranean Theater of Operations|Mediterranean Base Section]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=bFIuAAAAMAAJ&q=robert+colglazier+mediterranean&dq=robert+colglazier+mediterranean&hl=en&ei=tqThTb-EEOXM0AHot7G7Bw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAw Hearing record], Hearings On Sundry Legislation Affecting the Naval and Military Establishments, US Senate Armed Services Committee, Issues 1-9, 1962, page 829 ==Post World War II== After the war Colglazier returned to San Antonio as President of the family business, now reorganized as Colglazier McKennon Construction, while also continuing to serve with the Army Reserve.[https://books.google.com/books?ei=kKfhTf2LBsHv0gGaz9iZBw&ct=result&id=Q5U3AQAAIAAJ&dq=Colglazier+McKennon+Construction&q=Colglazier#search_anchor The Military Engineer], published by Society of American Military Engineers, 1951, Volume 43, page 478 ==Korean War== In 1951 Colglazier was recalled to active duty for the [[Korean War]]. His assignments included several positions in the office of the Army's Deputy Chief of Staff for Logistics, G4, where he coordinated the flow of supplies and equipment into [[South Korea]] and was recognized for his expertise in the field of military logistics management.[https://books.google.com/books?id=dHgzth4m6toC&q=robert+colglazier+korea&dq=robert+colglazier+korea&hl=en&ei=2qvhTYvOAarL0QHuoNyGBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwADgK Hearing record on H.R. 8873], Department of Defense Appropriations for 1955, US Senate Appropriations Committee, 1954, page 421[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/450259682.html?dids=450259682:450259682&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Jun+01%2C+1954&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Army+Called+Too+Weak+for+Global+War&pqatl=google Newspaper article, Army Called Too Weak for Global War], Los Angeles Times, June 1, 1954[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6gMjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Hs4FAAAAIBAJ&pg=1052,25294&dq=colglazier+army&hl=en Newspaper article, Army Can't Fight Global War With Cutbacks, Congress Told], by United Press International, published in Palm Beach Post, June 1, 1954 ==Post Korean War== After the Korean War Colgaizer was assigned as commander of [[United States Army Europe|U.S. Army Europeâ€™s]] Communications Zone, serving from 1956 to 1957.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=frVFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XM8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=1669,1071344&dq=colglazier+army&hl=en Newspaper article, Army Orders French Cars for Staff Use], Portsmouth (Ohio) Times, July 5, 1956[https://books.google.com/books?ei=86_hTYn1Ocnn0QGA7OmGBw&ct=result&id=nCkvAAAAMAAJ&dq=colglazier+commander+us+army+europe+communications+zone&q=colglazier#search_anchor Hearing Record], Military Posture Briefings: Hearings Before the Committee on Armed Services, US House of Representatives, 1961, page 829 From 1957 to 1959 Colgaizer was the Army's Assistant Deputy Chief of Staff for Logistics.[https://books.google.com/books?id=Jnl9p4Aw3pIC&q=colglazier+Assistant+Deputy+Chief+of+Staff+for+Logistics&dq=colglazier+Assistant+Deputy+Chief+of+Staff+for+Logistics&hl=en&ei=gq7hTcjuDeXZ0QH6o_SVBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwADgU Hearing record], Hearings Before the Committee on Armed Services of the House of Representatives on Subjects Affecting the Naval and Military Establishments], 1958, page 339 In 1959 he was named Deputy Chief of Staff for Logistics, receiving promotion to Lieutenant General and serving until 1964. At the time of his promotion Colgaizer was the highest ranking reservist serving on active duty. During this assignment Colglazier oversaw modernization of weapons and vehicles and an increase in procurement as the Army's effort in Vietnam increased.[https://books.google.com/books?ei=iK3hTfHvHqbg0QH8tu23Bw&ct=result&id=N-wXAQAAMAAJ&dq=colglazier+commander+us+army+europe+communications+zone&q=colglazier#search_anchor Army, Navy and Air Force Journal], published by Army and Navy Journal Inc., 1959, Volume 96, Issues 27-52, page 1336[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1777349972.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Feb+10%2C+1963&author=&pub=The+Sun+(1837-1985)&desc=New+Weapons+Needs+Laid+To+Earlier+False+Economy&pqatl=google Newspaper article, New Weapons Needs Laid To Earlier False Economy], Baltimore Sun, February 10, 1963[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/csmonitor_historic/access/218723352.html?dids=218723352:218723352&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&date=Feb+03%2C+1964&author=&pub=Christian+Science+Monitor&desc=Army+Plans+Funds+For+Battle+Copters&pqatl=google Newspaper article, Army Plans Funds For Battle Copters], Christian Science Monitor, February 3, 1964[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1707850312.html?FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Aug+26%2C+1960&author=&pub=The+Sun+(1837-1985)&desc=Army's+M48+Tanks+Upheld+At+Hearing&pqatl=google Newspaper article, Army's M48 Tanks Upheld At Hearing], Baltimore Sun, August 26, 1960[https://books.google.com/books?id=G1NrzaxzRN4C&pg=PA182&dq=colglazier+army&hl=en&ei=WcbhTZ3iFcbr0gHOqZmfBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q=colglazier%20army&f=false Women's Army Corps, 1945-1978], by Bettie J. Morden, 1990, page 182 ==Vietnam War== From 1964 to 1966 Colglazier commanded the Fourth Army in San Antonio.[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/580091732.html?dids=580091732:580091732&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Mar+25%2C+1964&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Navy%2C+Army+Brass+Shifted%2C+Promoted&pqatl=google Newspaper article, Navy, Army Brass Shifted, Promoted], Chicago Tribune, March 25, 1964[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ydlOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LksDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5404,1512187&dq=robert+colglazier+fourth+army&hl=en Newspaper article, Phase-out of Reserves to be Slow], by Associated Press, published in Victoria (Texas) Advocate, December 13, 1964[http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50716FE3E5910728DDDA80894DA405B868AF1D3 Newspaper article, 4th Army Head Retires], New York Times, February 1, 1966 During his command he was dispatched to Louisiana by President [[Lyndon Johnson]] to coordinate disaster relief efforts following [[Hurricane Betsy]].[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/938325722.html?dids=938325722:938325722&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Sep+12%2C+1965&author=&pub=Hartford+Courant&desc=Johnson+Speeds+Aid+To+Stricken+Louisiana&pqatl=google Newspaper article, Johnson Speeds Aid To Stricken Louisiana], Hartford Courant, September 12, 1965[https://books.google.com/books?ei=DsfhTbXoIMnu0gGXhe2HBw&ct=result&id=tH_VAAAAMAAJ&dq=colglazier+army&q=colglazier#search_anchor Texas Highways], Texas Highway Department, 1965, Volumes 12-13, page 162 During his command Colgaizer also generated headlines when he reduced the sentence of Private First Class Winstel R. Belton, who had gone on a hunger strike to protest orders to report to [[Vietnam]]. Belton was originally sentenced to five years imprisonment, but Colglazier reduced the penalty to a one-year suspended sentence, provided that Belton report to Vietnam, which he did.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=P2dFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=O7wMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2892,5095479&dq=robert+colglazier+fourth+army&hl=en Newspaper article, Hunger Strike Sentence Will be Suspended], by Associated Press, published in Dubuque (Iowa) Telegraph-Herald, September 30, 1965[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=F0UaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ticEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7445,80828&dq=robert+colglazier+fourth+army&hl=en Newspaper article, Probe Asked on Leniency to PFC Belton], Milwaukee Journal, October 11, 1965[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/629457052.html?dids=629457052:629457052&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Oct+10%2C+1965&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Rip+Leniency+for+GI+Balking+at+Viet+Duty&pqatl=google Newspaper article, Rip Leniency for GI Balking at Viet Duty], Chicago Tribune, October 10, 1965[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dPUeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-YsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4513,1597786&dq=colglazier+army&hl=en Newspaper article, Ex-Hunger Striker on Way to Viet Nam], by Associated Press, reported in Sarasota Journal, October 14, 1965 ==Awards== His personal decorations included the [[Distinguished Service Medal (U.S. Army)|Distinguished Service Medal]], [[Legion of Merit]], [[Bronze Star Medal]], [[Army Commendation Medal]], [[Order of the British Empire]], French [[Legion of Honor]] and French [[Croix de guerre#French Croix de guerre|Croix de Guerre]].[http://militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipient.php?recipientid=100083 Valor Awards for Robert W. Colglazier], Military Times Hall of Valor, accessed may 28, 2011[https://books.google.com/books?id=hO_Hk9xiBhUC&q=robert+colglazier+%22legion+of+merit%22&dq=robert+colglazier+%22legion+of+merit%22&hl=en&ei=tJvhTbK6K8n10gG958CGBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA Biographical sketch, Robert W. Colglazier], Hearing record, Committee for Special Investigations, US Senate Armed Services Committee, 1963, Volume 2, page 788[http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0717FB3B581B7B93C5A91782D85F478485F9 Legion of Merit is Awarded to 20; Fifteen Officers and Five Enlisted Men are Honored by the Army], New York Times, September 7, 1943 ==Military retirement and later career== Colglazier retired from the Army in 1966. In retirement he remained active with Texas A&M, serving as councilman-at-large for the Association of Former Students. He was named a Texas A&M Distinguished Alumnus in 1971.Newspaper article, Texas A&M Names 3 San Antonians, San Antonio Light, August 8, 1971 In 1997 he was inducted to the Texas A&M Corps of Cadets Hall of Honor.[http://corps.tamu.edu/about-the-corps/1997-hall-of-honor-inductees.html 1997 List of Inductees], Texas A&M Corps of Cadets Hall of Honor, accessed May 28, 2011 ==Death and burial== Colglazier resided in San Antonio and died there on January 23, 1993.Social Security Death Index[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SAEC&p_theme=saec&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F2231506E6BC550&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Newspaper obituary, Colglazier, 88, Army general], San Antonio Express, January 25, 1993 He was buried at [[Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery]], Section AI, Plot 644.[http://gravelocator.cem.va.gov/j2ee/servlet/NGL_v1 Nationwide Gravesite Locator], Department of Veterans Affairs, accessed May 28, 2011 ==External Resources== *[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=508339 Find A Grave page], Robert W. Colglazier, Jr., accessed May 28, 2011 ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Colglazier, Robert Wesley, Jr.}} [[Category:Military personnel from St. Louis]] [[Category:People from San Antonio]] [[Category:Texas A&M University alumni]] [[Category:United States Army Command and General Staff College alumni]] [[Category:United States Army generals]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:American military personnel of the Korean War]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Service Medal (United States)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Legion of Merit]] [[Category:Recipients of the Bronze Star Medal]] [[Category:1904 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:Burials at Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery]]
